channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [GROOVY-9807] Static compile of dynamically generated code produces different output in a top-level class and a nested class
item.description:
I have encountered an issue when trying to generate code, containing chained method calls, at runtime (without source code) and compiling using CompileStatic.
What I am trying to achieve is produce code similar to:

public StringBuilder test() {
    StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder().append("testString");
    return sb;
}

I create the appropriate AST nodes, statements, expressions, etc.
Everything works fine if I add a method like the one shown in a top-level class (the class is also dynamically generated at runtime). However, if I try to add the exact same method to a nested class, it seems like the groovy compiler gets somehow confused and, judging by the decompiler output, produces something like:

public StringBuilder test() {
    StringBuilder sb = ((StringBuilder)((Closure)this).getThisObject()).append("testString");
    return sb;
}

Naturally, this does not work.

Here's how I try to generate the method:

ClassNode topLevelClass = ClassHelper.make(
    "com.example.groovycompiler.test.TopLevelClass");
InnerClassNode nestedClass = new InnerClassNode(
    topLevelClass,
    "com.example.groovycompiler.test.TopLevelClass$NestedClass",
    Opcodes.ACC_PUBLIC | Opcodes.ACC_STATIC,
    ClassHelper.OBJECT_TYPE);
ClassNode stringBuilderClass = ClassHelper.make(StringBuilder.class);
nestedClass.addMethod(
    "test",
    Opcodes.ACC_PUBLIC,
    stringBuilderClass,
    Parameter.EMPTY_ARRAY,
    ClassNode.EMPTY_ARRAY,
    block(
        declS(
            varX("sb", stringBuilderClass),
            callX(ctorX(stringBuilderClass), "append",
                args(constX("testString")))),
        returnS(
            varX("sb", stringBuilderClass))
    )
);

Perhaps I am missing something, in which case I will be very happy to receive some pointers.
I have created a github repo with a maven project containing a unit test that demonstrates the issue: https://github.com/l-atanasov/groovy-static-compile-issue
Note, that I have extended the CompilationUnit a little to allow to run the static compiler without source.

Also, if I am not using the static compiler, everything works as expected.

Update: reformatted code for readability
item.environment:
openjdk version "1.8.0_242"
OpenJDK Runtime Environment (build 1.8.0_242-8u242-b08-0ubuntu3~18.04-b08)
OpenJDK 64-Bit Server VM (build 25.242-b08, mixed mode)
item.summary: Static compile of dynamically generated code produces different output in a top-level class and a nested class

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
When you create the return statement, you may need the variable expression to reference the declared local variable instance.

VariableExpression var = varX("sb", stringBuilderClass);
block(
  declS(
    var,
    callX(ctorX(stringBuilderClass), "append", args(constX("testString")))),
  returnS(
    varX(var))
)

This may be a good case for using the macro function so that the AST creation details are left up to the compiler (if you use Groovy for your transform). You can plug this into the Groovy console and at least get the AST structure you would need to generate.

def block = macro {
  StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder().append("testString")
  return sb
}

Also, since you are mixing in static compilation, it is important to know at what compile phase you are making your AST transformation.

One potential source of problems for your inner class scenario is that your example creates a new ModuleNode for each ClassNode.  All the types that are located in the same source "file" should be in the same ModuleNode.  So when you add a ClassNode for compilation, you would also include inner classes.  You may also have multiple top-level ClassNode instances in a ModuleNode if you wish.

You are actually quite close on your solution. The callX factory method does not set the implicitThis property and so it defaults to true. Setting it to false and the inner class method works properly.

Here is a self-contained script that can be tried in the Groovy Console or Groovy Shell or wherever:

import static groovyjarjarasm.asm.Opcodes.*
import static org.codehaus.groovy.ast.tools.GeneralUtils.*

import org.codehaus.groovy.ast.*
import org.codehaus.groovy.control.*
import org.codehaus.groovy.control.customizers.*

import groovy.transform.CompileStatic

GroovyClassLoader load(ClassNode type) {
  CompilerConfiguration config = new CompilerConfiguration()
  config.addCompilationCustomizers(new ASTTransformationCustomizer(CompileStatic))
  new GroovyClassLoader(Thread.currentThread().getContextClassLoader(), config).tap { loader ->
    SourceUnit source = new SourceUnit("${type.nameWithoutPackage}.groovy", null, config, loader, null)
    ModuleNode module = new ModuleNode(source)
    module.setPackageName(type.packageName)
    module.addClass(type)
    for (def iter = type.getInnerClasses(); iter.hasNext(); ) {
      module.addClass(iter.next())
    }
    CompilationUnit unit = new CompilationUnit(config, null, loader)
    unit.getAST().addModule(module)
    unit.compile(Phases.CLASS_GENERATION)
    for (groovyClass in unit.getClasses()) {
      defineClass(groovyClass.name, groovyClass.bytes)
    }
  }
}



ClassNode topLevelClass = ClassHelper.make('test.TopLevelClass')
ClassNode stringBuilderClass = ClassHelper.make(StringBuilder.class)
org.codehaus.groovy.ast.expr.VariableExpression var = varX('sb', stringBuilderClass)
//topLevelClass.addMethod('test', ACC_PUBLIC, stringBuilderClass, Parameter.EMPTY_ARRAY, ClassNode.EMPTY_ARRAY,
//  block(
//    declS(var, callX(ctorX(stringBuilderClass), 'append', args(constX('testString')))),
//    returnS(varX(var))
//  )
//)
ClassNode nestedClass = new InnerClassNode(topLevelClass, topLevelClass.name + '$NestedClass', ACC_PUBLIC | ACC_STATIC, ClassHelper.OBJECT_TYPE)
nestedClass.addMethod('test', ACC_PUBLIC, stringBuilderClass, Parameter.EMPTY_ARRAY, ClassNode.EMPTY_ARRAY,
  block(
    declS(
      var,
      callX(
        ctorX(stringBuilderClass),
        'append',
        args(constX('testString'))
      ).tap {
        setImplicitThis(false) // XXXX: this is the critical missing piece
      }
    ),
    returnS(varX(var))
  )
)

Class<?> compiledClass = Class.forName('test.TopLevelClass$NestedClass', true, load(topLevelClass))
StringBuilder result = compiledClass.newInstance().test()
print result

Thank you for the time you took to look over this issue!
I tested the solution and indeed implicitThis in MethodCallExpression was the culprit. Setting it manually to false seems to resolve the issue.
I couldn't help but notice, however, that the javadoc for MethodCallExpression.isImplicitThis() states the following:

@return true if no object expression was specified otherwise if
some expression was specified for the object on which to evaluate
the method then return false

I am obviously providing an object expression. Maybe I do not understand something here, but is this a case of outdated documentation, or could this be considered a small bug in the MethodCallExpression constructor? The constructor doesn't change the flag value regardless of whether the object expression is null or not.

The description of implicitThis is reasonable, but could probably be clearer. I think it is referring to what you might see in source code. We often create MethodCallExpression instances with an object expression of VariableExpression("this") or "delegate" or "owner" to represent the implicit case and so you need the flag to disambiguate. Also, I think if you have an object expression that does not reference a local variable or parameter, you could still have an implicit-this condition.

It has been mentioned in other bugs and probably on the mailing list (citations needed) that this flag is a concern being defaulted to true. I'm not sure there is a clear course of action in changing it safely. I believe its meaning has been overloaded in some of the classgen code. Maybe changing it for the GeneralUtils#callX factory method is a smaller change that can be tried.

I see. I consider my issue resolved by calling setImplicitThis(false) on a method expression when I am calling a method on local variable.
I would suggest adding some documentation to the GeneralUtils#callX methods that explains this condition, so people like me, who try to do some non-trivial transformations, don't get confused in the future. Maybe even add an overload, or just similar new methods to GeneralUtils that create MethodCallExpression instances with implciitThis set to false. That would add a little more convenience when transformations are written in plain Java.
The only thing that still baffles me is why there is different behavior between a top-level class and a nested static class. If I don't set implicitThis to false in the top-level class, I still get the desired result. I think that a nested static class should be more or less the same as a top-level class, since it shouldn't hold any special references.
